awd_titl_txt: II-New: TurboRAN: Testbed for Ultra-Dense- Multi-Band Control and Data Plane Split Radio Access Networks of the Future
awd_abstract_narration:
A key requirement from emerging next-generation (5G) cellular networks is that they must be rapidly adaptable to a broad range of use cases. This problem calls for a big shift in the way cellular radio access network architectures are designed and operated. One way forward is to explore novel radio access architectures such as Control and Data Plane Split Architecture (CDSA), and equip them with next generation Pro-active Self-Organizing Network functions (P-SON). Under this approach, small cells may operate on millimeter wave bands and provide high data rates to users on demand.  Overlaid macro-cells that operate on sub-6 Gigahertz (GHz) frequency bands provide control functions to support these users while providing lower data rates. To translate this approach into pragmatic architectures and solutions, there is a need for a purpose-built testbed, as most existing testbeds don't have the flexibility and end-to-end programmability to investigate CDSA and P-SON. This project will develop TurboRAN: Testbed for Ultra-Dense-Multi-Band Control and Data Plane Split Radio Access Networks of the Future that aims to meet these needs.  

Impacts of TurboRAN include: 1) Enabling experimental research on P-SON, CDSA, and its variants, among various other system-level aspects of 5G wireless systems and beyond, with reproducible results; 2) Validating theoretical- and simulation-based systems research conducted by the wireless community; 3) Providing open access to cellular system control and user planes in a multi-tier cellular network; 4) Training a generation of wireless engineers leveraging innovative and experimental teaching; 5) Testing novel approaches and protocols for developing prototypes and shortening the research cycle towards rapid commercialization trajectory; 6) Developing joint academic-industry programs for conducting research aimed at rapid production uptake and promoting standards and thus acting as an innovation gateway. The proposed project is led by the team at The University of Oklahoma in conjunction with a number of domestic and international academic and industry partners interested in facilitating experimental investigation on future cellular systems.

TurboRAN will comprise three layers of cells, supporting operation in sub-6GHz bands as well as in millimeter wave bands, with conventional heterogeneous as well as C-RAN implementation. It will support MIMO, mobile access points and diversity of user devices. In addition to end-to-end programmability and flexibility for modelling a variety of futuristic heterogeneous cellular system scenarios, another unique feature of the TurboRAN project will be the integrated big data processing capability to explore the potential of untapped cellular control and user plane data for designing a proactive next-generation self-organizing network.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The core outcome of this NSF funded project is the creation of a novel end-to-end programmable testbed for emerging and future mobile networks, such as 5G and beyond, called TurboRAN.

 

Many existing mobile network testbeds use commercial vendor-provided mobile network equipment. While these testbeds offer features similar to a commercial mobile network, they lack flexibility and programmability for experimentation. On the other hand, to achieve greater flexibility and programmability  some testbeds use software defined radios (SDR). However, most of these SDR based testbeds do not include complete RF chains and mobility management features  to offer over the air multi-cell testing environment. Such testbeds only allow experiments on physical, link, and MAC layers often in single cell scenario, or multi-cell scenario with no user mobility support. Besides, most existing testbeds are not designed to create system level data lakes to enable research on AI-based optimization and automation the network. In contrast, the TurboRAN's intellectual merit stems from its end-to-end programmability, over-the-air interface with mobility support, and integrated data collection and processing capabilities. These features bridge a signficant gap in system-level experimental research, making TurboRAN the first testbed to enable system-level research on AI-based zero-touch automation solutions for emerging networks.

 

Through this ambitious NSF-funded project, the team has successfully designed, developed, installed, tested, and commissioned TurboRAN as a close replica of a commercial mobile cellular network with indoor and outdoor cell deployments. It physically covers the entire University of Oklahoma-Tulsa Campus. However, unlike commercial networks and other testbeds, TurboRAN users can configure and tune a large number of network parameters to set up a wide range of experiments, validating theoretical or simulation-based research on emerging mobile networks.

 

With a flexible coverage area exceeding 360,000 square meters and over 48 switchable and overlapping cells operable at three different frequencies projected from 16 outdoor antennas, TurboRAN can model diverse cell densities and operational configurations of interest in emerging mobile networks.

 

Managed by the AI4Networks Research Center (www.ai4networks.com) at the University of Oklahoma, Tulsa, academic and industry research community members can access this platform for their research. Below is a list of salient features that make TurboRAN a powerful and versatile novel platform for enabling unprecedented system-level research towards AI-enabled mobile networks:

  • TurboRAN is an over-the-air testbed, capturing real propagation and interference characteristics in a multi-cell, multi-user environment.

 

  • Featuring a 3GPP compliant 5G Core (5GC) and LTE (4G) Evolved Packet Core (EPC), TurboRAN enables system-level research on current and next-generation mobile networks.

 

  • Supporting user mobility and handovers, TurboRAN allows handover parameter configuration, opening new doors for mobility-related experiments.

 

  • This novel testbed enables experimental testing, evaluation, and data gathering for static and dynamic parameters associated with a multi-cell, multi-tier, multi-band cellular network, offering end-to-end programmability and a high degree of adaptability in RAN. Examples of tunable parameter include: cell configuration parameters, mobility management parameters, cells selection and reselection parameters, admission control parameters, cell individual offsets (CIOs), coverage footprints, frequency reuse, and remote antenna tilt (RET), to name just a few.

 

 

  • TurboRAN supports a large number of virtual user equipment (UE) to emulate congestion and various IoT scenarios.

 

  • TurboRAN features an application (developed by project team) for real-time data gathering from connected test mobile devices. The system includes a data logging app that is capable of logging network performance data and GPS location information in real-time. This data is then transmitted instantly to an online database, where it can be accessed immediately for faster analysis, decision-making and for processing and utilization in data-driven zero touch automation solutions. The data logging app is capable of logging important performance metrics, including RSRP, RSRQ, Timing Advance, Cell ID, BS ID, location, mobile device ID, and date and time at which the data was gathered.

 

  • Built with an integrated remote data collection interface and a compute cluster-based big data processing capability, TurboRAN allows exploration of untapped potential of network telemetric data to design and evaluate AI-enabled proactive automation solutions.

More detailed features and capabilities of this novel testbed can be found at the TurboRAN website: https://ai4networks.com/turboran/

 

The project's broader impact includes hands-on extensive training of over fifteen graduate students, including several female and minority students, on TurboRAN. Many of these students have won distinctions and awards at university level and international level.  Each project trainee now contributes to strengthening the US mobile network industry. The project has also resulted in a brand-new course focused on experimental research using TurboRAN, continuing the training future wireless engineers through experiential learning at the OU-Tulsa campus. Many significant project outcomes are disseminated via dozens of publications, often prepared in collaboration with the industry, sharing insights and lessons learned from the project.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/16/2023
Modified by: Ali Imran

por.por_txt_cntn:
The core outcome of this NSF funded project is the creation of a novel end-to-end programmable testbed for emerging and future mobile networks, such as 5G and beyond, called TurboRAN.

 

Many existing mobile network testbeds use commercial vendor-provided mobile network equipment. While these testbeds offer features similar to a commercial mobile network, they lack flexibility and programmability for experimentation. On the other hand, to achieve greater flexibility and programmability  some testbeds use software defined radios (SDR). However, most of these SDR based testbeds do not include complete RF chains and mobility management features  to offer over the air multi-cell testing environment. Such testbeds only allow experiments on physical, link, and MAC layers often in single cell scenario, or multi-cell scenario with no user mobility support. Besides, most existing testbeds are not designed to create system level data lakes to enable research on AI-based optimization and automation the network. In contrast, the TurboRAN's intellectual merit stems from its end-to-end programmability, over-the-air interface with mobility support, and integrated data collection and processing capabilities. These features bridge a signficant gap in system-level experimental research, making TurboRAN the first testbed to enable system-level research on AI-based zero-touch automation solutions for emerging networks.

 

Through this ambitious NSF-funded project, the team has successfully designed, developed, installed, tested, and commissioned TurboRAN as a close replica of a commercial mobile cellular network with indoor and outdoor cell deployments. It physically covers the entire University of Oklahoma-Tulsa Campus. However, unlike commercial networks and other testbeds, TurboRAN users can configure and tune a large number of network parameters to set up a wide range of experiments, validating theoretical or simulation-based research on emerging mobile networks.

 

With a flexible coverage area exceeding 360,000 square meters and over 48 switchable and overlapping cells operable at three different frequencies projected from 16 outdoor antennas, TurboRAN can model diverse cell densities and operational configurations of interest in emerging mobile networks.

 

Managed by the AI4Networks Research Center (www.ai4networks.com) at the University of Oklahoma, Tulsa, academic and industry research community members can access this platform for their research. Below is a list of salient features that make TurboRAN a powerful and versatile novel platform for enabling unprecedented system-level research towards AI-enabled mobile networks:

TurboRAN is an over-the-air testbed, capturing real propagation and interference characteristics in a multi-cell, multi-user environment.


 

Featuring a 3GPP compliant 5G Core (5GC) and LTE (4G) Evolved Packet Core (EPC), TurboRAN enables system-level research on current and next-generation mobile networks.


 

Supporting user mobility and handovers, TurboRAN allows handover parameter configuration, opening new doors for mobility-related experiments.


 

This novel testbed enables experimental testing, evaluation, and data gathering for static and dynamic parameters associated with a multi-cell, multi-tier, multi-band cellular network, offering end-to-end programmability and a high degree of adaptability in RAN. Examples of tunable parameter include: cell configuration parameters, mobility management parameters, cells selection and reselection parameters, admission control parameters, cell individual offsets (CIOs), coverage footprints, frequency reuse, and remote antenna tilt (RET), to name just a few.


 

 

TurboRAN supports a large number of virtual user equipment (UE) to emulate congestion and various IoT scenarios.


 

TurboRAN features an application (developed by project team) for real-time data gathering from connected test mobile devices. The system includes a data logging app that is capable of logging network performance data and GPS location information in real-time. This data is then transmitted instantly to an online database, where it can be accessed immediately for faster analysis, decision-making and for processing and utilization in data-driven zero touch automation solutions. The data logging app is capable of logging important performance metrics, including RSRP, RSRQ, Timing Advance, Cell ID, BS ID, location, mobile device ID, and date and time at which the data was gathered.


 

Built with an integrated remote data collection interface and a compute cluster-based big data processing capability, TurboRAN allows exploration of untapped potential of network telemetric data to design and evaluate AI-enabled proactive automation solutions.


More detailed features and capabilities of this novel testbed can be found at the TurboRAN website: https://ai4networks.com/turboran/

 

The project's broader impact includes hands-on extensive training of over fifteen graduate students, including several female and minority students, on TurboRAN. Many of these students have won distinctions and awards at university level and international level.  Each project trainee now contributes to strengthening the US mobile network industry. The project has also resulted in a brand-new course focused on experimental research using TurboRAN, continuing the training future wireless engineers through experiential learning at the OU-Tulsa campus. Many significant project outcomes are disseminated via dozens of publications, often prepared in collaboration with the industry, sharing insights and lessons learned from the project.
